bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, March 27, 1941

div1.p: Kean asserts that Finlay was the discoverer of the transmission of yellow fever by mosquito and that Reed's demonstration of the theory led to its acceptance by the scientific world. He expresses a dislike for the grouping of men in the yellow fever painting.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, March 27, 1941
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
March 27/41
My dear Dr Hench
div1.p:
Your letter mailed on the
20th was received on the 24th. I noted
the date on the Envelope. I have had
it upright on my desk waiting the
note book containing, photostat
copies of the articles by Hemmeter
and Donnally about Carroll.
I am Keen to see them but they
have not yet arrived, at which
I am puzzled. I will wait no
longer to send you a letter to
Havana. You will arrive there to-
morrow and I will send this to the
Hotel Facional, Havana.

I have written to Dr. Angles, and
Dr. Francisco Dominguez. I have a
AC
K
2
long letter from Dr. D. beautifully written
in French. He thinks that Finlay
is next to Pasteur, so there is no
use to argue with him. We agree
that Finlay was the discoverer of
the transmission of y. f. by the mos-
quito and that Reed and his
assistants demonstrated it so
that it was accepted by the scientific
world. I do not see why sensible
scientific men should dispute
over the relative credit of each.
Yes I have the key you sent me to
your dispatch box. I kept it inten-
tionally so that you could make
other shipments if you wished, like
these Hemmeter photostats. I will
give it to you when you come here
in April. It will be fine to
have a day of talk with you.
3
Yes I will round up a Stenog. For you and
have her on hand. I know only one and
she has a job at the Military Surgeon. If
she cannot get a day off you can comman-
ders one from one of your medical friends
here as you suggest.

Colonel Siler brought me today photographic
copies of Reed's contracts with four of the
Spaniards also a photograph of the Canvas
bag which held the $600 00 in gold for three
of them. I took out Beniño's gold prices
myself. I think before the others. I asked
Col. Siler to have these printed for you and
he made two sets, one for you and one for me.
He brought me also an armful of records
from the files of the Military Surgeon. I will
look over these before you come to see if
there is any thing that you want there.
I was Sec'y & Editor of the Military Surgeon
from the date of my retirement from active
duty in 1924 until 1934 when I resigned
as Editor and Secy.

I hope that you will find smooth sailing in
Cuba - and get all the cooperation that you
want. I have just heard that my best friend
in Cuba Dr. Jose M. Peña is dead of a cancer
of the pancreas. He was a man of stirling char-
acter and good business capacity and great
loyalty to his friends. He was my assistant
first in Beneficencia and, in the second Inter-
vention, in Sanidad - and we exchanged occa-
sional letters through more than 30 years.
I will talk to you about the painting when I
see you. I do not like the group at all but do not
4
but I have not any desire to assert
my opinion in the matter in opposi-
tion to yours and Trubys. I know that
Reed would hate to see that impos-
sible group brought together, as if
for a photograph, when he was in Washing
ton and Agramonte, probably in Havana
and the whole thing was at that time
a deep secret. I really think the
Finlay-Reed group in the patio is much
better, if Lazear is given a prominent
place. Carroll probably wasn't there and
if he was, was utterly sceptical.
I feel that Reed's fame is so secure
that neither the partizan spirit of Dr
Dominguez & the Cubans nor any picture
that can be painted can harm it.
Here is the end of the page & a good place
to stop
